title: Taskflow: A Lightweight Parallel and Heterogeneous Task Graph Computing System

sections.heterogeneous scheduling algorithms:
Among various heterogeneous runtimes,
work stealing is a popular strategy to reduce the complexity of
load balancing  
and has inspired the designs of many
parallel runtimes     .
A key challenge in work-stealing designs is worker management.
Instead of keeping all workers busy most of the time   ,
both oneTBB  and BWS 3 have developed sleep-based strategies.
oneTBB employs a mixed strategy of fixed-number worker notification,
exponential backoff, and noop assembly.
BWS modifies OS kernel to alter the yield behavior.
 takes inspiration from BWS and oneTBB to develop an
adaptive work-stealing algorithm to minimize the number of wasteful steals.
Other approaches, such as  that targets a space-sharing environment,
 that tunes hardware frequency scaling,
2  that balance load on distributed memory,
1 7   that deal with data locality,
and  that focuses on memory-bound applications
have improved work stealing in certain performance aspects, but their results
are limited to the CPU domain.
How to migrate the above approaches to a heterogeneous target remains an open question. In terms of GPU-based task schedulers,
Whippletree [ref]50 design a fine-grained resource scheduling algorithm
for sparse and scattered parallelism atop a custom program model.
 leverages reinforcement learning to place machine learning workloads
onto GPUs.
Hipacc  introduces a pipeline-based optimization for CUDA graphs
to speed up image processing workloads.
[ref]55 develops a compiler to transforms OpenMP directives to a CUDA graph.
These works have primarily focused on scheduling GPU tasks in various applications,
which are orthogonal to our generic heterogeneous scheduling approaches.
